group_1.textLeft: ...It appears we've been separated.
The emergency door seems to be broken,@so we should prioritize our evacuation.

group_1.textRight: No, I think we should focus on finding@Shioya and the others first.
I'm sure they're worried about@being cut off too...right?

group_1.textLeft: Aimlessly searching around without any@idea of their location is too inefficient.
...That's why it's more logical to focus on@getting out of here than trying to find the others.
Furthermore, although we haven't been@able to confirm any fires so far,
the fire alarm did still go off, and we have no way@of knowing whether it was genuine or not.
Thus, we should assume the worst-case scenario@and prioritize getting to safety.

group_1.textRight: But we can't leave Shioya behind...!

group_1.textLeft: ...Judging by their positions earlier,@your girlfriend is probably with Kokoro.
As Kokoro is an avid hiker with@some degree of survival know-how,
she's most likely prioritizing evacuation as well.
I believe your chances of meeting up with@them will be higher if you do the same.
Of course, it's your decision to make.@If you want to search for her, you can.
But as you're Kanagi's little brother,@and younger than I am,
do keep in mind that I'm responsible for your safety.

group_1.textRight: ...Aren't you worried about your own partner?

group_1.textLeft: ...It isn't that I'm not worried, but as things stand,@I know that she'll be fine.
Yes. I like to think that I'm aware of her capabilities.
...So I'm going to focus my efforts on getting out.@And you?

group_1.textRight: ...Hey, do people ever tell you they@can't tell what you're thinking?

group_1.textLeft: I don't believe you can ever really know@what other people are thinking.
But...yes, I've experienced that. And you?

group_1.textRight: Like, how she has a hard time telling my@thoughts and stuff unless I say them out loud.
...But it's kinda hard for me to do that.

group_1.textLeft: ...I see. I don't know if it's quite the same,
but I am dealing with a similar issue myself.
One that leads to disagreements, eventually@causing conflicts like the one you saw earlier.

group_1.textRight: ...I figured it'd be fine as long as we're both on the@same page, even if I didn't put it all into words...

group_1.textLeft: Yes, that's being lazy.

group_1.textRight: Whaâ€• Damn, you turned on me quick...!

group_1.textLeft: I don't recall ever taking your side.
If Kokoro believes that words are@the key to mutual understanding,
then words I shall use.
But as for how much to say, and when...
I still haven't figured those out.
We had a fight earlier, and I'm trying to reflect on it.
That's why I'm practicing saying more.
Communicating without words...@To me, that's just a fantasy.
If that were possible, there'd be no conflict.

group_1.narration: "I refer to Kamihama City's@persistent East-West conflict...@The Kamihama Student Conference, formed as a@united front against this issue;@and the two inspiring members that bonded@across borders as a new generation's hope."

group_1.textLeft: Aren't you two this so-called "couple@that united the East and the West"?
I'd expect you, with that position of yours, to@understand the importance of verbal discourse.
And from a logical perspective, for two individuals@with at least some degree of intimacy,
it's much faster to discuss issues than to end@up fighting from the ensuing misunderstanding.
...Kokoro's anger earlier was an example of this,
but a misunderstanding could obscure even that,@leading to a truly time-consuming resolution.
Since when was there ever a fixed standard@for a relationship to begin with?
...We might want to rethink our escape plan a bit.
